content:
Hi!

@David Ross and myself are interested in contributing to chalk over the next couple of weeks. We are planning to meet every Saturday to work on it. We were previously contributing to rustc but are interested in working on Chalk, as it is a little more approachable with our limited time.

We are planning to pick up some good first issues to get warmed up. However, we are hoping to eventually do something more substantial, does anyone have suggestions for an area we could focus on longer term?

@Super Tuple I haven't missed this :) Was a busy weekend for me, so wasn't able to respond to this. Long story short, we are going to probably a few different things to work on for the next sprint (starting next Tuesday)
Most of the things to do are somewhat centered around rustc integration
I'll think about this more, but I we'll figure out more about what we plan to get done for the next 6 weeks tomorrow at the design meeting (4PM EST) if you want to join
Yeah! This is exciting. @Super Tuple and @David Ross we can try to keep an eye out for some work items tomorrow -- would you both like to tackle the same problem, or perhaps two related problems?
Hello! Since this topic has come up, I would like to say that I would be very excited to work on chalk as well, if possible

nikomatsakis said:

Yeah! This is exciting. Super Tuple and David Ross we can try to keep an eye out for some work items tomorrow -- would you both like to tackle the same problem, or perhaps two related problems?

Sorry we didn't get back on this! One item between us would be good.

I realize we missed the deadline for the pre-sprint meeting on March 24th - so if there isn't anything to be assigned that's understandable. If there's anything small or less blocking, though, would there still be an opportunity for next Tuesday?

We've also both enabled zulip notifications now! We'll try to be in better communication.
@David Ross checkout out this Hackmd (https://hackmd.io/kYWsWI9IS0213x0qX_1RDw?both) and see if there's anything you're interested in?
There's plenty to do :)

Oh- awesome! A lot of those look interesting, but also daunting / open.

Do you know if anyone's working on creating a .chalk file from a given program?
Yeah, some can definitely be daunting. But feel welcome to ask questions here!
Nobody is currently working on that
I have a branch somewhere where I started on that
let me try to find it

David Ross said:

Oh- awesome! A lot of those look interesting, but also daunting / open.

Yeah, I feel the same -- I'm also interested in contributing here if I can but I'm not sure where to start. I'm very comfortable with Rust but new to contributing to Rustc!
(not saying it's going to be the right way to approach it, but would be a good start)
Here is the branch: https://github.com/jackh726/chalk/commit/c43f1a1bf7446e5a71298395c300e257d504fc1e
This was really just a start. Really, we would want it to be at the chalk_ir level, not chalk_integration
@Mark McCaskey did you look at the hackmd? Is there something in particular that piques your interest?
If not, I can probably recommend a couple
Generating .chalk files is indeed a good one to start with, as it doesn't require too much knowledge with how program clauses work under the hood, while giving a chance to get familiar with them
(plus it will be super useful in general)
Cool! We'll start working on that then

@Jack Huey Yeah, the impl trait and unification of Rustc and Chalk types seem interesting! I found https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/368 and that actually seems like a good place to start -- thanks!

David Ross said:

Cool! We'll start working on that then

Awesome! Like I said, feel free to ask questions if you have any. I'll be around more on the weekends than @nikomatsakis
Will do, thanks! I guess I'll start a new zulip thread for that? Fairly new to the system
Yeah, feel free

Mark McCaskey said:

Jack Huey Yeah, the impl trait and unification of Rustc and Chalk types seem interesting! I found https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/368 and that actually seems like a good place to start -- thanks!

Yeah, adding type names is a good place to start! Same thing, if you have questions, feel free to ask
I'll also @rustbot assign you both to the issues on github so we don't lose track
Err, I actually don't know both of your github users. So feel free to @rustbot claim the issues :)
I don't think the chalk repo is set up to let anyone do rustbot claim, but I've assigned the issues anyways :sweat_smile:
@detrumi Thanks for assigning us. I deleted my @rustbot claim message in an attempt to remove noise, and that seems to have unassigned me. Could you re-assign me? Sorry :(
haha
I was very confused for a second. Of course!
(makes sense: not everyone has permission to assign issues, but you can always unassign yourself)
we recently set up the rustbot?
https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/commit/328f6b74304eb87836ec501206b0e7b8da16dcad
that's weird it didn't work
@Jack Huey Can you point me to the issue where it didn't work?
see https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144729-wg-traits/topic/triagebot
https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/365#issuecomment-609079931
@simulacrum ^
I'll take a look
okay, figured it out, rustbot needs to be added to the repo, doing so now
@simulacrum @rustbot claim was assigning issues to rustbot, are we using it wrong or do we need to configure it? (this happened in https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/363 earlier)

this is expected for some cases because of how github works: you can only assign issues to some people, like all the org members, not everyone. When it can, it'll assign like you'd expect, but when it can't, it'll "soft assign" via a comment on the first message in the issue: "This issue has been assigned to Areredify via this comment." like here
Note also that GitHub has a bug in their API, once someone comments on an issue, they can be assigned, but I believe there's no way to do it through the API.
weird

Hey, since you mentioned it in yesterdays meeting:
I wanted to ask which tasks I could help with, since I'm unsure where to start. I've done a little bit of rust in the last six months, read most of the blog posts and followed the messages in this stream for some weeks, but nonetheless I'm a little unsure, where exactly I can help/which tasks are not already worked upon.
We have some chalk issues labeled good first issue, some of which are free to be picked up
This is an easy one to start out with: chalk#380
Looks like some of the others with that label are already being worked on. chalk#306 is still free, but looks a bit more difficult to start with
You mind if I try and tackle https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/380 ?
go ahead, first come first serve :upside_down:

Nice! I would be interested in trying https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/chalk/issues/306 too but if it is significantly harder, then I might need a bit more hand holding. Then again.. this is how you learn I guess :)
I guess the chalk book is a good start for this one
@Zahari Dichev so, for that issue
I think we just want to add Floundering if the Environment gets too large
Here: https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/blob/master/chalk-solve/src/solve/slg.rs#L356
but actually, we definitely don't want to accidentally leak that environment truncation, if we ever add truncation back in
so, this might be worth blocking on making the truncation a Visitor
at the very least, truncate_goal should be changed to have a return type of Result<(), Floundered>
if no overflow, return Ok(()). Otherwise, returned Err(Floundered)
note that this might make some tests ambiguous where we found an answer before

Side thought: (c.c. @nikomatsakis) I actually do think it would be useful to add truncation back in, in some form (eventually). Right now, we disallow goals like Vec<Vec<Vec<....<T>...>>> by just checking the type size. But when we potentially have to deal with large types (think maybe like a chain iterator), we would have to set that limit large. But we don't want to recurse into that Vec... that deep.
I'm curious how the recursive solver might change this or not need it
You'd only need to expand such goals if there are rules that nest Vec that deeply, otherwise it shouldn't be necessary to go further than the first step
@Jack Huey thanks a lot. I submitted an issue to avoid leaking the truncated result. Wrt to making the truncation a visitor. Is there an issue for that one that I can pick up ?
Sorry, I might've (definitely) introduced a bunch of merge conflicts in your pr :P
Yeah, I am not sure my PR is actually relevant anymore. No worries, will find something else.
Hi @Zahari Dichev, see my comment: https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/392#issuecomment-612967074
tldr: these changes are superseded by the visitor change, but you can change it to solve rust-lang/chalk#306
Thanks a lot !
@Jack Huey I was wondering whether there is anything else that I can take on that can be a nice intro to the codebase?
Stick around for the meeting, we will find something cool
yes, that
or
see this: https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144729-wg-traits/topic/more.20issues/near/193669641
Let me see if I can narrow that done to a couple that are especially good
Is there something in particular that you're interested in?
If you want to do a little investigation (which would help you have a "goal" when looking around through the codebase bit), then this PR/issue would be good
@Zahari Dichev
@Florian Diebold has a fix there, but I have a hunch that there might be something subtle happening
But looking over it again, it also just might be because of the way we handle Floundering

@Jack Huey I will look at it nevertheless, it certainly will result in me learning something new. But anything else you can think of that is a good way to get familiar with the core concepts will probably be great. I am quite interested in the performance work that will mostly likely happen at some point. Kind of feel that I need a bit more breadth and depth before I can have a meaningful stab at it though. Hence looking for some more "getting familiar issues"
@Areredify I will not be able to stick around for the meeting unfortunately (its getting a bit late here), but if you could pretend I am there, that will be much appreciated ;)
Yeah, if you want to start with this, let's investigate and figure out if merging this PR is good or if there's a different/additional fix needed.
Then after that, I can mentor you through performance-related work :)
Specifically, for this issue/PR, I would start by pulling Florian's branch, rebase, and making sure the that the added test and the test in the comments both pass
It seems like the one in the comments doesn't? @Florian Diebold
Just created https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/397 which might be a good first issue
Perfect, will look at them both !

Jack Huey said:

It seems like the one in the comments doesn't? Florian Diebold

With my change, it produces the wrong result, yeah. I don't think it's really caused by my change though (I don't think peek_answer should change the behavior in that way?), rather that makes it hit that edge case. I added the second test to the PR, with the currently wrong result so it passes
Right, this is basically what I said in the comments
that I think there's something else happening here
yes, I think the "answer cached" case in any_future_answer is wrong
